instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Just got this in today with liquid damage. When connected to the charger with a battery it gets 5V 0.33A and the Apple chips get very hot. Noticed it has a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> with removed F5200.

Seems like will have to buy FlexBV to be able to go through the board view. Where shall I start? Is it worth it, considering apple chips are getting hot?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Check if any big coil gives same resistance to ground as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Only the three coils (3.8V power supply) next to the Apple chip seems to be 33Ohm with removed Fuse
[ATTACH type="full" alt="1631786577193.png"]60160[/ATTACH]

Lifted them and seems all three are connected to one spot on the Apple chip side. And the short is on that side. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>  short is gone once they are lifted up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Then at least one of <TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>/20/40 is shorted...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
If you are referring to the MOSFETs between those three coils and the caps in the picture above. They do not seem short. The left side of the coils towards the apple chip, are joined together and is 33Ohms. <SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON</SIGNAL> side I believe

Seems like I need to get the board view, but either way no donor board for these MOSFETs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
I cannot see too much in that small picture.
If you get 0 ohm between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> and these coils, then one of mentioned chips is shorted.
These chips must have a marking code, which identify them as dual N-channel MOSFET.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
For some reason, i could not post a bigger picture.
I've lift them up at X places and short is here
[ATTACH type="full" alt="1631793408910.png"]60162[/ATTACH]

Seems like VDD of <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>. Perhaps busted <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>? Is that the Apple chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
33 ohm to ground could be correct value on <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>, but not on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
I said to check for pure short BETWEEN <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>, not to ground!
Such short may only be induced by one of <TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>/20/40.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
You were right the one in the middle is shorted. Any suggestion what donor board I can have this mosfet on? I have <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> boards from never gen macs. Do you have an idea of the specs of the mosfet. AONE36196, DA37EK search didn't bring much?

[ATTACH type="full"]60163[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
No information at all; just buy (hopefully) new one:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://es.aliexpress.com/item/1005003187610175.html?spm=a2g0o.productlist.0.0.3f55647bKmjP7V&algo_pvid=bc31703a-c938-4e1a-b9f6-b85a43e4b8ca&algo_exp_id=bc31703a-c938-4e1a-b9f6-b85a43e4b8ca-0&pdp_ext_f=%7B%22sku_id%22%3A%2212000024565678968%22%7D[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Got the mosfets today. Slightly different markings 36196 .
Replaced the shorted one in the middle and still stuck on 5V 0.15A

Seems like the 3.8V controller is heating up to 38*C at room temp 20*C. Cant measure any other shorts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage - short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Do you get correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> now?

One of the chips powered from <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> can be damaged by overvoltage through the burnt MOSFET; possibly <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>, or <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>.
<CHIP>U5700</CHIP> is also suspect.
